doc.title: Filelmann Group
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Fielmann Group Management confident in a better 2HFielmann Group Management confident in a better 2H_2025-08-29

passages.text: Reiterate Rating: NEUTRAL | PO: 60.00 EUR | Price: 56.4€ EUR

With a \(4.4\%\) 1H OSG vs \(4\%\) in 1Q but \(5.1\%\) when adjusting for sales days, Filelmann's management acknowledges that 1H does not compare well with the \(5 - 6\%\) average seen since 2019 (including COVID) and with the \(c.5\%\) it envisions for its optometry business in the next five years. The DACH countries grew a healthy \(c.5\%\) at cc on our estimates vs \(4\%\) in 1Q. But Spain slowed from \(9\%\) in 1Q to \(7\%\) in 2Q, and the US sales dropped \(3\%\) vs 1Q in dollar terms on our estimates. 2H outlook: Unchanged close to €2.5bn FY sales target, implying a \(5 - 6\%\) 2H growth, with several supportive factors: i) US demand acceleration; ii) large number of doctor hirings this summer in the US, fuelling sales growth going forward; iii) ongoing marketing campaigns, notably in Germany.

At \(23.7\%\) in 1H (24% FY target), the 1H margin enables the group to confirm its FY guidance. Yet, after the strong 1Q (24.2%), 2Q's \(23.2\%\) margin deserved to be clarified. Key factors: i) GM down 190bp vs 1Q due to high sunwear sales at a low margin; ii) opex only down 70bp sequentially, due to marketing spend phasing. 2H Outlook: with steady European and rising US margins in 2H, the group confirms its FY targets, and highlighted possible mitigation actions if needed: cost benefits of merging the 2 US assets (possible job cuts); more selectivity on marketing expenses (€84m FY budget including €44m spent in 1H); tighter control of the store network expansion.

We slightly erode our FY25 adj. EBITDA to €587m (c.580m guidance) and we maintain our €60 PO and Neutral rating. Investment case: i) no material Bloomberg ccs EPS change since the May upgrades; ii) the 12m fwd EPS growth is gradually slowing (28% YoY in May and 25% currently), and this should carry on (we expect the trend back to the low teens starting next year); iii) the strong stock performance in 1H led the 12m fwd PE back above 20x. However, the risk premium should not shrink further in our view, as the group is about to present its new MT ambitious plan: \(>60\%\) revenue growth in 5 years, o/w a quarter from M&A (mostly in the US), OSG acceleration (to \(c.7\%\) in our estimates) starting next year, while slightly raising the adj. EBITDA margin to \(25\%\) .

1H comments: with a \(4.4\%\) 1H OSG vs \(4\%\) in 1Q but \(5.1\%\) when adding for sales days, Fielmann's management acknowledges that 1H does not compute well with the group's \(5 - 6\%\) average seen since 2019 (including COvD) and with the \(4.5\%\) it envisions in its optometry business for the next five years, in newly announced 2030 targets. More specifically, the DACH countries (Germany, Austria, Switzerland - \(75\%\) of 1H25 sales) grew a healthy \(c.5.5\%\) at cc on our estimates vs \(4\%\) in 1Q. On the other hand, Spain ( \(8\%\) of 1H25 sales) slowed from \(9\%\) to \(7\%\) in 2Q, and the US revenues ( \(12\%\) of 1H25 sales) dropped \(3\%\) in 2Q vs 1Q in dollar terms on our estimates (management highlighting market share losses in the group's regions of operations).

2H outlook: the group maintains its close to €2.5bn FY sales target, implying a \(5 - 6\%\) 2H growth, highlighting a series of supportive factors: i) US demand acceleration since May, including in July; ii) large number of doctor hirings this summer in the US, fueling sales growth going forward; iii) ongoing marketing campaigns, notably in Germany.

1H comments: at \(23.7\%\) in 1H ( \(24\%\) FY target), including \(24.8\%\) in Europe (FY target of \(25\%\) ) and fast rising \(14.9\%\) (vs \(2.2\%\) in 1H24) in North America (unchanged mid- high teens FY margin target), the 1H margin enables the group to confirm its FY guidance. On the other hand, after the strong 1Q ( \(24.2\%\) ), 2Q's \(23.2\%\) margin deserved to be clarified. Key factors: i) gross margin down 190bp sequentially vs 1Q (vs 120bp last year) due to particularly high sunwear sales at a low margin; ii) opex only down 70bp sequentially (vs 150bp last year), due to marketing spend phasing. It was €8m above 1Q spend. In fact, correcting for these €8m, the 2Q adjusted EBITDA margin would have been slightly above 1Q's margin, on our estimates.

2H outlook: with steady European and rising US margins in 2H, the group confirms its FY targets. Moreover, although its growth strategy limits the potential for cost cuts, the CFO highlighted possible mitigation actions if sales falter: cost benefit of merging the 2 US assets bought recently (possible job cuts in back office, insurance handling, and finance functions); more selectivity on marketing expenses (€84m FY budget including €44m spent in 1H); tighter control of the store network expansion.

CC: constant currency  CS: Consensus  CMD: Capital markets day  DACH countries: Germany, Austria, and Switzerland  GM: Gross margin  MT: medium term  OSG: Organic sales growth

Our €60 PO is based on i) a DCF valuation (assumptions in our model include a WACC of \(9\%\) and a terminal growth rate of \(3\%\) ), ii) a peer group average multiple, with a mix of eyewear and audiology peers and retailers in other industries. WACC: breakdown: \(4\%\) risk- free rate, beta of 1. Terminal growth rate of \(3\%\) : \(2\%\) of volume growth and \(1\%\) of price boost.

Upside risks to our price objective include better- than- expected activity on an organic basis (double digit growth in the US?), and well priced M&A combined with successful and swift integration of the acquisitions. Downside risks include more exposure to FX risk and to the potentially volatile US economy, and risks around the M&A strategy (price, integration etc.).

Taiwan Readers: Neither the information nor any opinion expressed herein constitutes an offer or a solicitation of an offer to transact in any securities or other financial instrument. No part of this report may be used or reproduced or quoted in any manner whatsoever in Taiwan by the press or any other person without the express written consent of BofA Securities. This document provides general information only, and has been prepared for, and is intended for general distribution to, BofA Securities clients. Neither the information nor any opinion expressed constitutes an offer or an invitation to make an offer, to buy or sell any securities or other financial instrument or any derivative related to such securities or instruments (e.g. options, futures, warrants, and contracts for differences). This document is not intended to provide personal investment advice and it does not take into account the specific investment objectives, financial situation and the particular needs of, and is not directed to, any specific persons(s). This document and its content do not constitute, and should not be considered to constitute, investment advice for purposes of ERISA, the US tax code, the Investment Advisers Act or otherwise. Investors should seek financial advice regarding the appropriateness of investing in financial instruments and implementing investment strategies discussed or recommended in this document and should understand that statements regarding future prospects may not be realized. Any decision to purchase or subscribe for securities in any offering must be based solely on existing public information on such security or the information in the prospectus or other offering document issued in connection with such offering, and not on this document.

Securities and other financial instruments referred to herein, or recommended, offered or sold by BofA Securities, are not insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and are not deposits or other obligations of any insured depository institution (including, Bank of America, N.A.). Investments in general and, derivatives, in particular, involve numerous risks, including, among others, market risk, counterparty default risk and liquidity risk. No security, financial instrument or derivative is suitable for all investors. Digital assets are extremely speculative, volatile and are largely unregulated. In some cases, securities and other financial instruments may be difficult to value or sell and reliable information about the value or risks related to the security or financial instrument may be difficult to obtain. Investors should note that income from such securities and other financial instruments, if any, may fluctuate and that price or value of such securities and instruments may rise or fall and, in some cases, investors may lose their entire principal investment. Past performance is not necessarily a guide to future performance. Levels and basis for taxation may change.

This report may contain a short- term trading idea or recommendation, which highlights a specific near- term catalyst or event impacting the issuer or the market that is anticipated to have a short- term price impact on the equity securities of the issuer. Short- term trading ideas and recommendations are different from and do not affect a stock's fundamental equity rating, which reflects both a longer term total return expectation and attractiveness for investment relative to other stocks within its Coverage Cluster. Short- term trading ideas and recommendations may be more or less positive than a stock's fundamental equity rating.
BofA Securities is aware that the implementation of the ideas expressed in this report may depend upon an investor's ability to "short" securities or other financial instruments and that such

action may be limited by regulations prohibiting or restricting "shortselling" in many jurisdictions. Investors are urged to seek advice regarding the applicability of such regulations prior to executing any short idea contained in this report.
Foei including ADRs, effectively assume currency risk.

BofAS or one of its affiliates may, at any time, hold a trading position (long or short) in the securities and financial instruments discussed in this report.
